prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GGD27 Strong Lines
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of several strong transitions. These are grouped together based on expected brightness and correlator restrictions. The goal is to observe the brightest transitions in a single observation to maximize dynamic range for weaker transitions. Bandwidths are selected to acheive sufficient sampling of the spectral lines while minimizing data rates.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
We use our low-resolution CARMA observations to estimate the necessary RMS for detection of SiO, CS, CH3OH, and 13HCO+. Of the species targeted, SiO is by far the weakest, with a flux density of 10 Jy towards MM1/2. Taking a worst-case scenario of one source having only 1/3 of the observed flux, and the largest deconvolved source size derived from (Fernandez-Lopez et al. 2011 AJ?142,97) ~2"x2", a flux of ~0.75 Jy is expected in a 1” ALMA beam. The requested sensitivity of 10 mJy provides a 75 sigma detection for this SiO flux. The CARMA observations targeted transitions with excitation energies < 100 K. Observed dust temperatures towards our targets are > 100 K. The transitions target in these basebands have excitation energies ~ 100 – 150 K, and should therefore be brighter than those observed with CARMA making this a lower limit. In order to avoid possible dynamic range issues arising from extremely bright HCO+ emission we target 13HCO+. For detection of 13HCO+, we scale the observed CARMA flux density by the isotopic abundance (Asplund et al. 2009 Annu. Rev. Astron. Astrophys.. 47,481), giving flux density of 3.3 Jy. Using the same assumptions as those of HCO+, we estimate a lower limit 275 mJy, or a 27.5 sigma detection. We note that clear detections of these species could be achieved with a higher requested RMS, but the increased sensitivity provides the possibility of detecting weaker, high-velocity components that may improve the quality of our analysis, and increases the total time required by less than 30 seconds.
GGD27 is a compact source with multiple arcsecond scale substructures. As detailed in the science justification, the smallest separation between substructures is 1”, while the largest is 7”. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine the clumpy structure that will likely be present, while still being relatively well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in GGD27 have been shown to vary in width, but we expect them to be ~4 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 8 resolution elements across the 4 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
While GGD27 is a large (tens of arcminutes) outflow, the region of interest, that is the cluster of protostars, has been shown to be relatively compact, on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target CS J = 5-4 (known to trace UV dominated gas), SiO J=6-5 (known to trace shocked regions), 13HCO+ (known to trace ionized gas), as well as several methanol transitions spanning a wide range of excitation energies to probe temperatures and excitation conditions within the source. Each of these molecules provides an independent constraint on these disparate, but important, processes and conditions.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraitns on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity: For HNCO, previous observations (Qui et al. 2009 ApJ?702,L66) show a flux of 480 mJy in a 3.5”x2.8” beam toward the molecular core, with considerably higher flux toward other sources. Assuming the flux is in fact on this scale and taking this as a lower limit, this give a flux of 50 mJy towards the weakest source in a 1” ALMA beam, yielding a 5 sigma detection of the weakest previously detected feautres at significantly higher spatial resolution. It should be noted that these observations targeted a transition with upper state energy of 100 K. Observed dust temperatures towards our targets are > 100 K. The HNCO transition targeted in this correlator configuration has an upper state energy of 125 K, and should therefore be brighter than those observed by Qui et al, making this a lower limit. For detection of 13CH3OH, we scale the observed CARMA flux density by the isotopic abundance (Asplund et al. 2009 Annu. Rev. Astron. Astrophys.. 47,481), giving flux density of 2 Jy. Taking a worst-case scenario of one source having only 1/3 of the observed flux, and the largest deconvolved source size derived from (Fernandez-Lopez et al. 2011 AJ?142,97),~2"x2", a flux of ~160 mJy is expected in a 1” ALMA beam. We note that clear detections of these species could be achieved with a higher requested RMS, but the increased sensitivity provides the possibility of detecting weaker, high-velocity components that may improve the quality of our analysis, and increases the total time required by less than 30 seconds.
GGD27 is a compact source with multiple arcsecond scale substructures. As detailed in the science justification, the smallest separation between substructures is 1”, while the largest is 7”. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine the clumpy structure that will likely be present, while still being relatively well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in GGD27 have been shown to vary in width, but we expect them to be ~4 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 8 resolution elements across the 4 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
While GGD27 is a large (tens of arcminutes) outflow, the region of interest, that is the cluster of protostars, has been shown to be relatively compact, on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target HNCO J = 12(0,12)-11(0,11) (known to trace shocked gas), as well as several 13CH3OH transitions spanning a wide range of excitation energies to probe temperatures and excitation conditions within the source. Each of these molecules provides and independent constraint on these disparate, but important, processes and conditions. The observation of the optically thin 13CH3OH isotopologue will be vital to constraining optical depth effects and providing accurate physical parameters for the densest gas.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraitns on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

Sensitivity:
We use our low-resolution CARMA observations to estimate the necessary RMS for detection of 13CS. For detection of 13CS, we scale the observed CARMA CS flux density by the isotopic abundance (Asplund et al. 2009 Annu. Rev. Astron. Astrophys.. 47,481), giving flux density of 5.5 Jy. Taking a worst-case scenario of one source having only 1/3 of the observed flux, and the largest deconvolved source size derived from (Fernandez-Lopez et al. 2011 AJ 142,97), ~2"x2", a flux of ~460 mJy is expected in a 1” ALMA beam.
To estimate the flux of target large organic species we use the observed CH3OCHO flux from our CSO observations. The total flux density observed in the CSO primary beam is 2.5 Jy. Without interferrometric observations it is difficult to estimate the expected flux. We note that CH3OCHO as well as our other targeted species are observed to have both extended and compact emission toward massive protostars. Taking an extreme lower limit of 1% of the flux is compact, this gives a flux of 25 mJy in a 1” ALMA beam. This extreme lower limit results in a 8 sigma detection. The abundance of our other targeted species is difficult to determine, as there is no definitive detection with from our CSO observations. From previous surveys of massive star forming regions (e.g. Nummelin et al. 2000 ApJs 128,213) the abundances of other targeted species is often of order, or greater than that of CH3OCHO, and the lack of detection with the CSO is likely due in part to beam dilution. The higher sensitivity of these observations is meant to ensure detection of all targeted species.
GGD27 is a compact source with multiple arcsecond scale substructures. As detailed in the science justification, the smallest separation between substructures is 1”, while the largest is 7”. The requested angular resolution of 1" is therefore provides both the resolving power to examine the clumpy structure that will likely be present, while still being relatively well-matched to the overall source size.
Spectral lines in GGD27 have been shown to vary in width, but we expect them to be ~4 km/s. We have therefore requested appropriate bandwidths to provide 8 resolution elements across the 4 km/s FWHM. This will provide sufficient resolution to perform the Guassian fits necessary to extract accurate line parameters (namely peak intensity and linewidth).
Imaging:
While GGD27 is a large (tens of arcminutes) outflow, the region of interest, that is the cluster of protostars, has been shown to be relatively compact, on the order of a few to ten arcseconds. Thus, the entirety of the region of interest is easily located within the primary beam of the telescope and is also less than the maximum recoverable scale for this configuration. As a result, we expect no significant loss of sensitivity.
Correlator Setup:
We have configured the correlator to target 13CS J = 5-4 (known to trace UV dominated gas), as well as transitions of CH3CH2CN, CH2CHCN, CH3OCHO, and HCOOH that have high transition strengths, and upper state energies appropriate for the observed 100 – 150 K dust temperatures in the source. 13CS will be used to constrain optical depth effects when assessing the relative importance of shock and UV processing. High sensitivity observations of the complex organic species will give information on spatial distribution that will be vital in generating refined chemical models of the source.
Calibration:
We have chosen the system-defined calibration as recommended.
Bandpass accuracy: We expect no complications in this regard.
Scheduling/time constraints: We have no scheduling or time constraints.
Data rate: Our data rate is within normal standards.
Special constraitns on standard observing modes: On-source time, and total observing time are all within norms. Our overheads are only a few percentage points over the recommended 30%.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The underlying processes that drive physical and chemical evolution of massive star-forming regions remains an open question. Recent high angular observations of the nearest massive star-forming regions have begun to elucidate these processes, however additional information is required. We propose to significantly further our understanding of chemical and physical evolution in massive start-forming regions through high angular resolution observations of key molecular tracers towards the massive star-forming complex GGD27.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
